PwP participants had a higher disinhibition rate compared to HC (saccades during delay period). PwP slower on all tasks compared to HC.

column2: Chrystalina A. Antoniades;Pedro Rebelo;Christopher Kennard;Tipu Z. Aziz;Alexander L. Green;James J. FitzGerald
column4: Pallidal deep brain stimulation improves higher control of the oculomotor system in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 14 PwP (8 Gpi-DBS, 6 STN-DBS). (b) 10 HC.
column6: Anti-saccade task (response inhibition). Also: Globus pallidus interna DBS ON/OFF, STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column11: Both STN-DBS and GPi-DBS reduced prosaccadic latency when ON vs OFF. Neither STN-DBS or GPi-DBS affected antisaccadic latency when ON vs OFF. GPi-DBS reduced antisaccadic error rate, whereas STN-DBS did not. STN-DBS does not affect saccadic response inhibition, but does speed responses for prosaccades. GPi-DBS reduces antisaccadic error rates, and the difference in error rates ON vs OFF is bigger than for STN-DBS.

column2: S. Bayard;E. Joly;P. Ghisletta;A. Rossignol;Y. Herades;C. Geny;M. C. Gely-Nargeot;L. Rochat
column4: A multidimensional approach to impulsivity in Parkinson's disease: measurement and structural invariance of the UPPS Impulsive Behaviour Scale
column6: UPPS Impulsive Behaviour Scale (impulsivity), Game of Dice task (reward processing/decision-making under risk).
column11: PwP-ICBs showed significantly higher impulsivity than HCs on all domains of the UPPS except sensation seeking. PwP+ICBs showed higher impulsivity compared to HCs on the UPPS in relation to: urgency, lack of premeditation, lack of perseverance, and sensation seeking. PwP+ICBs had significantly higher sensation seeking scores on the UPPS compared to PwP-ICBs. PwP made more risky decisions than HCs on Game of Dice task. In PwP, higher risk taking on the Game of Dice task is associated with lack of premeditation (UPPS) and longer disease duration, whereas lower risk taking is associated with lack of perseverance (UPPS). Disease duration is associated with lack of premeditation and lack of perseverance (both on the UPPS).

column2: Nikoletta Bodi;Szabolcs Keri;Helga Nagy;Ahmed Moustafa;Catherine E. Myers;Nathaniel Daw;Gyorgy Dibo;Annamaria Takats;Daniel Bereczki;Mark A. Gluck
column4: Reward-learning and the novelty-seeking personality: A between- and within-subjects study of the effects of dopamine agonists on young Parkinson's patients
column5: (a) 26 de novo PwP (18 male), age 44.8 (5.2). UPDRS 30.8 (6.4), H&Y 1-3, duration since diagnosis 3.2 (2.0) months. (b) 22 medicated PwP (17 male). UPDRS 27.5 (6.1), H&Y 1-3, duration since diagnosis 8.8 (3.5) months. (c) 20 HC (15 male), age 45.3 (8.5).
column6: Probabilistic classification task (reward and punishment learning), Temperament and Character Inventory (personality traits). Also: commencement of medication.
column11: De novo PwP participants showed increased sensitivity to learning by punishment than medicated PwP participants, but less sensitivity to learning by reward. Compared to HCs, both PwP groups were impaired on reward learning, but de novo PwP outperformed HCs on learning by punishment. Medicated PwP participants had higher novelty seeking scores than HCs and de novo PwP. HCs had higher novelty seeking scores than de novo PwP. Positive correlation between novelty seeking and reward learning for medicated PwP. Positive correlation between punishment learning and harm avoidance for HCs. After commencing DA agonist treatment, the newly medicated (previously de novo) PwP group showed improved reward learning, disrupted punishment learning, and increased novelty seeking. They performed similarly to HCs for reward learning, but worse for punishment learning.

Suggests medication and DBS independently contribute to more advantageous behaviour, but no significant interaction of the two. No effect of medication or DBS on the use of negative feedback to make more advantageous decisions.
